subject: Travel
subcategory: The Story of Maps and Navigation
title: Indoor Navigation

hook.text: GPS doesn't work inside buildings. Finding your gate at a massive airport is still a guessing game.

buildup.text: Indoor positioning uses Wi-Fi signals, Bluetooth beacons, and magnetic field patterns to locate you.

discovery.text: Airports, malls, and hospitals are installing beacon networks. Your phone can navigate aisle by aisle.

twist.text: Stores use the same beacons to track your path through the shop and push ads as you walk past products.

climax.text: Apple and Google both added indoor maps. Future buildings will be navigable down to the room.

punchline.text: Indoor GPS is coming. So is indoor surveillance.

quiz.question: Why doesn't GPS work well inside buildings?
options: Satellite signals can't penetrate walls and ceilings
